paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b retain any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation, and if so, what is its composition and pressure?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: TRAPPIST-1 b Phase Curve
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: One orbital phase curve of TRAPPIST-1 b
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Phase-resolved thermal spectra of the rocky exoplanet TRAPPIST-1 b obtained with the JWST MIRI instrument to constrain day-night heat transport and spectral features.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-Rock Model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: The null hypothesis model assuming a bare-rock surface with no atmosphere and minimal day-night heat redistribution, used as a baseline for comparison.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-Rich Atmosphere Model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere retrieval models specifically designed to test scenarios with a significant presence of carbon dioxide as a greenhouse gas, causing spectral absorption features.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
